intro: Rosa virginiana subsp. humilis, commonly known as the sweetbriar rose, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and features thorny stems and pinnately compound leaves. The plant produces fragrant, pink to white flowers in the spring, which are followed by red, hairy hips. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and along stream banks. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental qualities and historical use in hedgerows and gardens.
